title: Galileo Galilei is born in Pisa
Galileo’s legendary demonstration on the Tower of Pisa
Robert Cardinal Bellarmine’s injunction to Galileo
Galileo publishes Dialogue concerning the Two Chief World Systems. The Inquisition orders Galileo’s publisher to cease publication of the Dialogue
Galileo appears before the Inquisition
Galileo publishes Discourses on Two New Sciences
Galileo dies in Arcetri. Isaac Newton is born in Woolsthorpe
Newton enters Trinity College, Cambridge University. 1665 Plague in England. Newton, in Woolsthorpe, begins to think about calculus, gravity, and optics
Newton is appointed Lucasian Professor of Mathematics at Cambridge
Newton’s reflecting telescope is demonstrated to the Royal Society
Newton publishes De Motu corporum in gyrum
Newton publishes the Principia
Newton moves from Cambridge to London
Newton publishes the Opticks. 1727 Newton dies in London
Michael Faraday is born in Newington, Surrey, now part of London
Sadi Carnot is born in Paris
Thomas Young discovers his principle of interference based on a wave model of light
Robert Mayer is born in Heilbronn
James Joule is born in
Hans Christian Oersted’s experiment demonstrating a magnetic effect produced by an electric effect

Hermann Helmholtz is born in Potsdam, Germany. Faraday’s experiment demonstrating electromagnetic rotation. Augustin Fresnel characterizes light as waves that vibrate perpendicularly to their direction of motion
1822 Rudolf Clausius is born in Koslin, Prussia
1824 Carnot publishes Reflections on the Motive Power of Fire

Faraday discovers electromagnetic induction. James Clerk Maxwell is born in Edinburgh, Scotland. Chronology of the Main Events 465 1832 Carnot dies in Paris. Faraday formulates the laws of electrochemistry
1834 Emile Clapeyron publishes a mathematical version of Carnot’s theory
Faraday studies electrostatic induction
Willard Gibbs is born in New Haven
Mayer publishes his first paper
Joule publishes his first determinations of the mechanical equivalent of heat
Ludwig Boltzmann is born in Vienna

Mayer publishes his second paper, including a calculation of the mechanical equivalent of heat. Thomson develops a mathematical theory of electrostatic lines of force. Faraday observes the effect of a magnetic field on polarized light

container-title: Helmholtz publishes On the Conservation of Force
title: Joule publishes results of his paddle-wheel experiments for determination of the mechanical equivalent of heat
Thomson publishes his thermometry principle

container-title: 1851 Thomson publishes On the Dynamical Theory of Heat
title: Clausius publishes his first paper on heat theory, in which he introduces the function U and derives the equation dQ ⫽ dU ⫹ PdV
1852 Faraday defends the reality of lines of force

note: Maxwell publishes his first paper on electromagnetism, On Faraday’s Lines of Force.
title: Thomson defines absolute temperature in terms of Carnot’s function. Clausius publishes his second paper on heat theory and derives a state function that would later represent entropy
Thomson joins the Atlantic Telegraph Company
Clausius publishes his first paper on the molecular theory of gases
Max Planck is born in Kiel
Maxwell publishes his first paper on the molecular theory of gases
Maxwell publishes his second paper on electromagnetism, On Physical Lines of Force
Walther Nernst is born in Briesen, West Prussia

note: Maxwell publishes his third paper on electromagnetism, A Dynamical Theory of the Electromagnetic Field.
title: Clausius publishes his last paper on heat theory, in which he completes his theories of energy and entropy, and states the two laws of thermodynamics
Faraday dies at Hampton Court, Middlesex, England. Maria Sklodowska is born in

note: Ernest Rutherford is born near Nelson, New Zealand.
title: Maxwell is appointed to the Chair of Experimental Physics at Cambridge. Helmholtz goes to Berlin
Gibbs publishes a geometrical interpretation of thermodynamics, with emphasis on the energy and entropy concepts
Gibbs publishes On the Equilibrium of Heterogeneous Substances

note: 1879 Maxwell dies in Cambridge, England. Albert Einstein is born in Ulm, Germany.
title: Lise Meitner is born in Vienna
Niels Bohr is born in Copenhagen
Erwin Schrodinger is born in Vienna
Clausius dies in Bonn
Joule dies in Sale, England. Edwin Hubble is born in Marshfield
1892 Louis de Broglie is born in Dieppe
Nernst publishes his textbook, Theoretische Chemie
Helmholtz dies in
1896 Boltzmann publishes the first volume of Lectures on Gas Theory. Henri Becquerel discovers the radioactivity of uranium
Boltzmann publishes the second volume of Lectures on Gas Theory. Marie and Pierre Curie announce their discoveries of polonium and radium

publisher: Wolfgang Pauli is born in Vienna
title: Planck publishes his paper on blackbody radiation, which, in a limited way, introduces the concept of energy quantization

note: Enrico Fermi is born in Rome.
title: Gibbs publishes Elementary Principles in Statistical Mechanics. Werner Heisenberg is born in Wurzburg

publisher: Patent Office. Paul Dirac is born in Bristol
title: Rutherford and Frederick Soddy publish a series of papers in which their transmutation theory of radioactivity is developed. Einstein is appointed technical expert third class in the
Gibbs dies in New Haven
Nernst goes to Berlin. Einstein publishes his papers on relativity, the photoelectric effect, and colloidal particles as molecules
Nernst publishes his heat theorem. Rutherford discovers α-particle scattering. Boltzmann dies in Duino, a village near Trieste, Italy
Thomson dies near Largs, Scotland
Hans Geiger and Ernest Marsden publish their paper on α-particle scattering by metallic foils
Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar is born in Lahore, then in India, now in Pakistan
Rutherford proposes the nuclear model of the atom
Einstein moves to Berlin. Bohr publishes his first paper on the structure of atoms and molecules
Henry Moseley publishes his papers on the x-ray spectra of the elements
Einstein publishes his paper on general relativity
Richard Feynman is born in Far Rockaway
Rutherford becomes director of the Cavendish Laboratory in Cambridge
The Bohr Institute is inaugurated in Copenhagen
De Broglie presents his theory of wave-particle duality for matter
Hubble reports cosmic distance measurements beyond our galaxy
Heisenberg publishes his first paper on matrix mechanics. Max Born, Heisenberg, and Pascual Jordan publish their comprehensive paper on matrix mechanics. Pauli introduces his exclusion principle

note: Fermi publishes his first paper on quantum statistics.
title: Schrodinger publishes his first paper on wave mechanics. Born publishes his first paper on the probability interpretation of quantum mechanics
Heisenberg proposes his uncertainty principle
Dirac introduces his relativistic electron equation

Murray Gell-Mann is born in New York. Hubble publishes his first paper on the linear relation between recession speeds of galaxies and their distances from Earth. Dirac introduces his hole theory, identifying a hole as a proton
Dirac proposes the existence of the antielectron, later called the positron. John Cockcroft and Ernest Walton study nuclear reactions with proton beams generated in a linear accelerator

note: Fermi publishes his paper on the theory of β decay.
title: Einstein moves to Princeton, New Jersey
Marie Curie dies in Sancellemoz, France. Chandrasekhar publishes his first white-dwarf paper
The particle later identified as the μ lepton is discovered
Meitner and Otto Frisch propose their theory of fission

Bohr and John Wheeler publish their paper on the mechanism of fission. Robert Oppenheimer, George Volkoff, and Richard Tolman propose a theory of neutron stars. Oppenheimer and Hartland Snyder show that an idealized imploding star forms a black hole
Nernst dies at his country estate near Bad Muskau

publisher: Stephen Hawking is born in Oxford
title: Fermi and associates achieve the first sustained nuclear chain reaction
Los Alamos National Laboratory begins operation near Santa Fe
Trinity test of a plutonium bomb near Alamogordo
The first two “V-particles” are discovered. George Gamow proposes a preliminary big-bang theory
Planck dies in Gottingen, Germany
The Pocono Conference meets. Ralph Alpher, Hans Bethe, and Gamow extend the big-bang theory
Chandrasekhar becomes managing editor of the Astrophysical Journal
Hubble dies in San Marino, California. Gell-Mann proposes the strangeness scheme
Chronology of the Main Events 1954 Fermi dies in Chicago
Einstein dies in Princeton
Conservation of parity in weak interactions is questioned by Tsung-Dao Lee and Chen Nin Yang. The electron neutrino is detected
Pauli dies in Zurich
Schrodinger dies in Alpbach, Austria. Gell-Mann proposes SU(3) symmetry for hadronic structure: the eightfold way
Bohr dies in Copenhagen. The μ neutrino is detected

note: is introduced. Roger Penrose proves that black holes must contain singularities.
title: The ⍀⫺ particle is discovered. Gell-Mann proposes the quark model, with three flavors of quarks. A fourth quark flavor, called “charm
The “color” concept is introduced in particle physics
Wheeler coins the term “black hole
Meitner dies in
Hawking and Penrose prove that the universe began in a singularity
Feynman proposes his parton model
The theory of asymptotic freedom and confinement of quarks is proposed

note: Hawking shows that black holes are not quite black.
title: Discovery of the J/␺ particle. Experimental evidence for the charmed quark is reported
The τ lepton is detected
Heisenberg dies in Munich
Experimental evidence for the bottom quark is reported
Experimental evidence for gluons is reported
Dirac dies in
De Broglie dies in Paris
Feynman dies in Los Angeles
Experimental evidence for the existence of only three generations of quarks and leptons is reported
Experimental evidence for the top quark is reported
The τ neutrino is detected

note: places Clausius’s work in its historical context.
title: Clausius is another physicist (like Carnot) who is on the biographically endangered list. The DSB article by Edward Daub is recommended
From Watt to Clausius

note: For that, see Martin Klein’s DSB article on Gibbs. J. G. Crowther has written briefly about Gibbs’s life in American Men of Science (New York: Norton, 1937).
title: Gibbs has two biographies: Muriel Rukeyser, Willard Gibbs
The History of a Great Mind
Neither biography does justice to Gibbs’s work as a scientist
Two nineteenth-century Faraday biographies are Henry Bence Jones, The Life and Letters of Faraday
Faraday as Discoverer
The principal twentieth-century Faraday biography is Pearce Williams, Michael Faraday: A Biography

For a more condensed version of Faraday’s work, see Williams’s DSB article on Faraday. Geoffrey Cantor discusses the religious dimension of Faraday’s life in Michael Faraday: Sandemanian and Scientist
Crowther tells about the ups and downs of the Davy-Faraday relationship in Men of Science
Faraday’s most famous lecture at the Royal Institution was published as The Chemical History of a Candle

container-title: Maxwell’s papers have been collected in The Scientific Papers of James Clerk Maxwell
title: The main Maxwell biography, written by his friend Lewis Campbell, is The Life of James Clerk Maxwell
Two more-recent biographies are C
James Clerk Maxwell: Physicist and Philosopher
The Demon in the Aether: The Story of James Clerk Maxwell
For the story of Hertz’s brief but remarkable life, see Charles Susskind, Heinrich Hertz: A Short Life

note: Boltzmann’s writings on gas theory are translated by Stephen Brush in Lectures on Gas Theory (New York: Dover, 1995).
title: Boltzmann has only two short biographies in English, Englebert Broda, Ludwig Boltzmann
and Carlo Cercignani, Ludwig Boltzmann: The Man Who Trusted Atoms
The story of Boltzmann’s confrontation with the antiatomists is told in David Lindley’s recent Boltzmann’s Atoms: The Great Debate That Launched a Revolution in Physics

note: Ronald Clark, Einstein: The Life and Times (New
title: The Einstein literature is overwhelming. The best of the many biographies is Abraham Pais, Subtle Is the Lord: The Science and Life of Albert Einstein
tells about Einstein’s public life. Einstein told his own story (briefly) as “Autobiographical Notes
A recent Einstein biography is Albrecht Folsing, Albert Einstein
In collaboration with Leopold Infeld, Einstein wrote an excellent introduction to modern physics, The Evolution of Physics

note: are revealing. Chapter 16
title: There is no full-length biography of Planck in English. John Heilbron writes about Planck’s preeminent role in the German scientific community in The Dilemmas of an Upright Man: Max Planck as Spokesman for German Science (Berkeley and Los
Planck’s own remarks in his Scientific Autobiography and Other Papers
The best biography of Bohr in English is Abraham Pais, Niels Bohr’s Times, in Physics, Philosophy, and Polity
Also see the collection of reminiscences about Bohr edited by Stefan Rozental, Niels Bohr: His Life and Work as Seen by His Friends and Colleagues
Niels Bohr
The story of Bohr’s efforts on behalf of an open nuclear policy is told in Alice Kimball Smith, A Peril and a Hope

container-title: Max Born, Physics in My Generation
note: is an account of the revolution that started with Einstein’s relativity theory and continued with the matrix mechanics created by Born, Heisenberg, and others.
title: The enigmatic Heisenberg has a full-length biography, David Cassidy’s aptly titled Uncertainty: The Life and Science of Werner Heisenberg
Heisenberg tells part of his own story in Physics and Beyond: Encounters and Conversations
Elisabeth Heisenberg
emphasizes her husband’s precarious status during the war years

container-title: Samples of his work can be found in What Is Life?
note: My View of the World (Cambridge: Cambridge
title: De Broglie has no full-length biography in English, not even a DSB entry. Schrodinger, on the other hand, has Walter Moore’s revealing Schrodinger: Life and Thought
An earlier biography is William T. Scott, Erwin Schrodinger: An Introduction to His Writings
Schrodinger was a prolific writer and lecturer
and Science and Humanism

container-title: and, in one volume, Marie Curie’s Autobiographical Notes and her loving biography of her husband, Pierre Curie
title: Marie Curie’s remarkable life is told in Susan Quinn, Marie Curie: A Life
Also see Eve Curie, Madame Curie

note: shows Rutherford in his middle period.

Feynman’s monologue books, autobiographies of a kind, are Surely You’re Joking, Mr
